```{r data generation, echo=FALSE, results='hide'}
pacman::p_load(exams, tidyverse)
choices <- character(4)
explain <- character(4)
choices[1] <- "`mean(x) Â± 1.96 * sd(x)`"
choices[2] <- "`mean(x) + c(-1, 1) * 1.96 * (sd(x)/sqrt(length(x)))`"
choices[3] <- "`t.test(x)$conf.int`"
choices[4] <- "`quantile(x, probs = c(0.025, 0.975))`"

explain[1] <- "The standard error should be calculated, instead of the standard deviation."

```

Question
============
You have a numeric vector `x` in R containing sample data. Which R command correctly computes a 95% confidence interval for the population mean?

```{r questionlist, echo=FALSE, results = "asis"}
answerlist(choices, markup = "markdown")
```


Solution
=================

A normal-theory confidence interval for a mean uses:
$$\bar{x} \pm z_{\alpha/2}\frac{s}{n}$$

The correct answer is

```{r solutionlist, echo = FALSE, results = "asis"}
answerlist(ifelse(sol, "TRUE", "FALSE"), explain, markup = "markdown")
```
